West of Hebron.

Beit Govrin in the 4th-2nd centuries BCE was situated in the heartland of Idumaean territory, touching on the Idumaean capital Marisa. It was conqured by Yohanan Hyrcanus I (in vol. 1, Yohanan [7] B/M, p. 134) toward the end of the 2nd century BCE and the inhabitants were forcefully and successfully converted to Judaism. Depending on the date of this tomb, its interred could be Jews or Idumaeans.

Biblical, e.g. Gen 35:18. בנימין is Jacob’s youngest son and one of the tribes of Israel
Biblical, e.g. Gen 30:11. גד was the name of one of Jacob’s twelve sons.
Biblical, e.g. Jer 40:5. גדליה was the Judaean prefect nominated by the Babylonians after destruction of the First Temple.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 16:13. דוד was the name of the famous king of Israel.
Biblical priestly course, see 1 Chr 24:18.
Biblical, e.g. Jer 42:1.
Biblical, e.g. Judg 12:13.

Biblical, Josh 7:1. This is a Second Temple name. During the Greco-Roman period forms of this name became popular among other Semitic peoples and it was not specifically identified with the Jews. Various forms of the name are recorded in Palmyra, see Stark, PNPI, 85-6; and in Idumea, see AOFCI, 99.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 30:6. זבלון was the name of one of Jacob’s twelve sons.
Biblical, see 1 Chr. 2:33.
Biblical, e.g. Zech 1:1. זכריה is the prophet who gave the name to the biblical book.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Kgs 16:9. The name is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 86).
Biblical, e.g. Haggai 1:12. חגי was the post-exilic prophet who gave the name to a biblical book.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 18:1. חזקיה was king of Judah.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 18:37.

Biblical, e.g. Jer 35:4. This name has such an independent standing that one often loses sight of the fact that it is probably an abbreviation of חנניה. Because this distinction is already biblical, I have not listed the two names under a single heading here.
Biblical, e.g. Jer 28:1.

Biblical, 1 Chr. 3:20. In vol. 1, (under חסדי S-H/M, pp. 384) I recorded variants of this name under Other (mostly Semitic) Names in the Hebrew Alphabet, because the biblical form of the name never showed up. In this volume does.
Biblical, e.g. Isa 4:6.
Biblical, e.g. Zech 6:10.
Biblical, e.g. Num 32:41.
Biblical, e.g. Zech 6:10. The longer form – יאשיהו – is the name of a king of Judah (2 Kgs 21:26).
Biblical, e.g. Gen 29:35. יהודה was one of Jacob’s sons, and a tribe of Israel.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 24:6. יהויכין was the name of one of the kings of Judah.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 23:34. יהויקים was the name of one of the kings of Judah.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Kgs 22:51. יהורם was the name of kings of Judah and Israel.
Biblical, e.g. Exod 17:9. יהושע was the name of the general, Moses’ successor, who gave his name to a biblical book.
Biblical, e.g. Jer 40:16.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 14:25. יונה was the prophet after whom a biblical book is called.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 13:2. יונתן was King Saul’s son.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 30:24. יוסף was a son of Jacob.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 25:26. יעקב is the third Patriarch.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 17:19. יצחק is the second Patriarch.

Biblical, e.g. Gen 16:11. ישמעאל, the first-born, rejected son of Abraham could not have been a likely role model for name giving. Nevertheless, it was very popular in post-biblical times, and seems to have already been in use among Jews toward the close of the First Temple Period (2 Kgs 25:25).
Biblical, e.g. Gen 32:29. Israel was the name given to the biblical Jacob.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 30:18. יששכר was a son of Jacob, and one of the tribes of Israel.

Biblical, e.g. Gen 29:34. לוי was a son of Jacob and one of the tribes of Israel. A relevant question is whether all persons named Levi in this period were Levites. On this see Stern, “Aspects of Jewish Society,” 599.
Biblical, Jer 32:12.

Biblical, e.g. 1 Chr 9:12. In vol. 1, (מלכה) S-H/M, pp. 390-1 and in vol. 3 (מלכא) S-H/M, pp. 674-7, I recorded variants of this name under Other (mostly Semitic) Names in the Hebrew Alphabet, because the biblical form of the name never showed up. In volume 4 and in this volume it shows up in the biblical form.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 15:14. מנחם was the one before last king of Israel.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 41:51. מנשה is Joseph’s son and one of the tribes of Israel.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 22:3.
Biblical, e.g. Jer 38:1.

Biblical, e.g. Ezra 10:43. This name is only documented in post-exilic biblical books (Ezra, Neh, 1 and 2 Chr). In Palestine this was a very popular Hasmonean name (see vol. 1, Introduction 1.1.1.2, pp. 6-7 and 191-6).
Biblical, e.g. Nah 1:1. נחום was the prophet who gave his name to a biblical book.

Biblical, e.g. 2 Sam 7:2. נתן was the name of David’s prophet. Because this is such an independent biblical name, one loses sight of the fact that it is in fact an abbreviation of a name such as יונתן or נתנאל, and is listed here under an independent heading.
Biblical, e.g. Num 1:8.
Biblical, e.g. Judg 3:12. Eglon was the name of the King of Moab who oppressed Israel.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 14:21. עזריה was a king of Judah.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 1:3. עלי was the priest who brought up Samuel.
Biblical, e.g. Amos 1:1. עמוס is the name of the prophet who gave the book the name.
Biblical, e.g. Exod 6:23.
Biblical, e.g. Exod 6:18. עמרם was Moses’ father.
Biblical, Neh 10:27.
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 2:45.
Biblical, 1 Chr 3:24.
Biblical, e.g. Exod 6:25. פנחס was the name of Aaron’s grandson. In the Bible the name is spelled as a rule פינחס.
Biblical, Num 34:25, and see also vol. 1, under Parnakh B/M, p. 208, n. 1.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Sam 15:24.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 29:32. ראובן was a son of Jacob and one of the tribes of Israel
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 9:2. שאול was the first king of Israel.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 25:3. Sheba was one of Abraham’s decendents from Qetura.
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 2:42.
Biblical, e.g. Ezra 10:15.
Biblical, see 1 Chr 7:36.
Biblical, e.g. Jer 37:3.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 1:20. שמואל was the prophet who gave his name to two biblical books.

Biblical, e.g. Gen 29:33. שמעון was a son of Jacob and one of the tribes of Israel. The name Simon is not only Jewish but also Greek. It was thus very popular among Jews, see under Simon (1) (B/M) in vol. 1, pp. 26-7. However, just because a person bears this name, it is not an indication that he is Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.4.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Kgs 12:22.
Biblical, e.g. 2 Kgs 22:3.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 4:25.
Biblical, 1 Chr 4:12.
